intro: Helopus bolbodes, commonly known as the globular bladderwort, is a unique aquatic plant characterized by its specialized, bladder-like structures. These bladders are used to trap small aquatic organisms, enabling the plant to obtain nutrients through a form of carnivory. The plant typically grows in shallow, freshwater environments such as ponds and slow-moving streams. Its stems are often submerged, with leaves that are modified into bladder-like appendages. Helopus bolbodes is a member of the Lentibulariaceae family, which includes other carnivorous plants.
